poster_metadata.display_title:
Lines on a Map, Lives in Motion:
Europe’s Ever-Changing Story

icon_badges.note: Legend icons include +/- badges indicating high vs low (crime is reversed).

raw_text.lowest_countries_values: Lowest Intake: Moldova (~2,700 cal), Albania (~2,800 cal)
Highest Crime: Russia (urban areas), Ukraine (conflict regions)

base_map_notes.note: Main map colored by per-country palette; on-map high/low markers implied by legend.

featurettes.title:
What’s the Difference?
Nations, Countries, and
States in Europe
featurettes.body_text:
Europe is home to many cultures, languages, and histories. Some groups
share traditions and see themselves as one people—these are called nations.
But a country or state is a place with borders, a government, and its own
laws. Sometimes a nation matches perfectly with a country, and we call that
a nation-state.

For example:
• Scotland has its own culture and history, so we call it a “country.” But
  Scotland isn’t independent—it’s part of the United Kingdom.
• The Basque people have their own language and traditions, but they live
  in parts of Spain and France without having their own separate country.
• France is a nation-state, where most people share French culture,
  and it’s fully independent.
• Russia is one country with many different nations inside it.

All over Europe, ideas about who belongs
to which nation, and who
controls which state, help shape
identities and sometimes cause
debates about independence or unity.

assets.description: Reference map highlighting Scotland within the United Kingdom (used as concept/reference; not clearly visible as a standalone inset on the proof).
Reference map showing the Basque region spanning Spain and France.
Reference image map of the Russian Federation by ethnic group (optional/extra; listed in docx but not clearly placed on proof).
Reference map of France location (nation-state example).
Venn diagram illustrating ‘Nation’, ‘Country’, and ‘Nation-State’ (custom vector diagram on proof).
Optional supporting photo (e.g., regional flags/identity imagery) to strengthen the featurette visually. Not specified on the proof; add if desired.

data_source_links.note: Specific map URLs are listed in asset hyperlinks.

chart_spec.layout_notes: Two-circle Venn: left labeled 'NATION (Shared Identity)', right labeled 'COUNTRY (Territory + Gov)', overlap 'NATION-STATE'. Example labels: Scotland (nation), UK (country).

featurettes.title:
Europe’s Changing Borders—A
Journey Through History
featurettes.body_text:
The map of Europe wasn’t always as it is today. Over the last century, wars, treaties, and
agreements have redrawn borders again and again. Before World War I, huge empires
ruled over many peoples. After the war, these empires broke apart, and new countries
appeared. After World War II, Europe split into East and West, divided by the Iron Curtain.
When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, the continent began to reunite, and as the Soviet Union
collapsed in 1991, more new countries emerged.

Each change in Europe’s borders affected the
lives of millions, sparking both struggles and
opportunities. Understanding how Europe’s
map evolved helps us appreciate the mix of
cultures and histories across the continent today.

assets.description: Map series showing Europe’s borders before WWI, after WWI, after WWII, and after 1991 (links point to example/reference maps).
Timeline of major events in Europe (e.g., Treaty of Versailles 1919, fall of Berlin Wall 1989).
Optional supporting photo (e.g., border crossing / passport stamp) to accompany the historical border-change narrative. Not on proof.

featurettes.title:
Growing Older—The Changing Faces
of Eastern Europe
featurettes.body_text:
In some parts of Eastern Europe, fewer babies are being
born while people live longer. Over time, this creates an
aging population, meaning there are more older people
and fewer young people to work, start new businesses,
or take care of those in need.

After the Soviet Union ended, many families decided to
have fewer children, and some young people left their
home countries for better opportunities elsewhere. This
can make it harder to keep economies growing and pay
for healthcare. Governments try to help by supporting
families, improving healthcare, and welcoming
newcomers. The story of Eastern Europe’s aging
population shows how history, economics, and personal
choices shape a region’s future.

assets.description: Horizontal bar chart comparing Europe’s age distribution (1920s vs 2023) across age groups (as shown on proof).
Chart showing declining birth rates (proof shows small-multiples style sample concept).
Optional supporting photo (e.g., multi-generational family / elders) to visually reinforce aging-population story. Not on proof.

featurettes.title:
Paris
The Heartbeat of France
featurettes.body_text:
Think of Paris as a shining star at the center of France. It’s a “primate city,”
meaning it’s much bigger and more influential than any other French city. Here,
fashion, art, and cuisine set trends that spread across the country and around
the world. Major companies, government offices, and world-famous museums call
Paris home.

Yet not everyone in France lives in this
bustling capital. Many live in quiet villages or
smaller towns, enjoying a slower pace of life.
While Paris’s energy helps drive the nation’s
economy and culture, people sometimes
worry about too much focus on one city.
Balancing the bright lights of Paris with the
rest of France’s landscapes and traditions is
an ongoing challenge.

assets.description: Photo pair: Eiffel Tower (Paris) and a peaceful countryside village (France).
Reference map of France highlighting Paris position (docx provides multiple candidate map images).
Bar chart comparing Paris population to other major French cities (Marseille, Lyon, Toulouse, Nice).

supplemental_stats_for_app.text: Italy is one of the highest per-capita consumers of bottled water globally, despite widespread access to clean tap water—reflecting cultural preferences and perceptions of taste.
Barcelona (Spain) is notorious for pickpocketing in crowded tourist areas (e.g., Las Ramblas) even though overall crime rates may be moderate.
Sweden has one of the highest proportions of single-person households globally—about 50% of households consist of one person.
